answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Jeffrey,
The following links should be useful for you. 
The Rio Arriba County, NM Sand and Mining Ordinance that includes restrictions on noise level, provides traffic control performance standards and reclamation requirements. 
http://www.rio-arriba.org/pdf/ordinance_sand__gravel.pdf 
The Cottonwood County, MN Ordinance for extracting sand sets aside special provisions for extractions in sensitive areas to mitigate risk of groundwater contamination and addresses violations and penalties. 
http://www.co.cottonwood.mn.us/Ordinance%20No.%2036.pdf 
The Wicomico County, MD Comprehensive Plan includes sand mining and outline Special Exception Conditions that ensure minimal damage to existing infrastructure and protection of the natural environment. 
http://www.wicomicocounty.org/departments/planning_zoning/compplan/CountyCP_CHAPTER%2013_Mineral%20Resources_9162010.pdf 
A Development Agreement between the City of Azusa, CA and Azusa Rock Inc. that outlines the environment impact assessment, public benefit and extraction tax and possible dispute and litigation proceedings. 
http://www.canyoncityalliance.com/about/Vulcan-City-of-Azusa-Development-Agreement-Final.pdf 
You may also find the article “Bristol residents challenge planners” useful as it illustrates the process between County and Citizens in the decision to allow sand and gravel extraction in the Conservation Zone. 
http://www.addisonindependent.com/201105bristol-residents-challenge-planners 
I hope that is helpful,
Pooja Varma
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Jeffrey French
text:
Barron County (B/C) is facing the situation in-which large mining and/or oil exploration concerns are prospecting and signing long term lease agreements with B/C citizens.  Specifically, the purpose of the lease is to extract large amounts of sand from hillsides to be processed into finished product which is then transported to an oil well site, typically, Texas or North Dakota and forced, fraced, into a horizontal oil well. The result is fracing extends the productive life of the oil well, in terms of years of production and oil quantity produced.  
My question is are there any other Counties or municipalities facing a situation similar to this?  If so, what are you doing about; zoning, road damage, quality of life issues, potentail environmental damage, citizen perception(s)?  Are you signing any type(s) of Developers Agreement with the mining companies and if so what are some attributes within these agreements?  
A second question:  If anyone in your municipality has expertise in this area are you willing to talk with me and the Barron County Board of Supervisors to help us?  We would be looking to get an understanding of potential pit-falls to avoid.
title: Frac Sand Mining & Accompanying Issues
